interpolate(xnew)ïƒ
Parameters

xnew â€“ list, new intensity vector

Return ynew

interpolated failure probabilities

Uses gam to interpolate the fragility curve data to a new x array. values above 1 are cliped.

  • xnew â€“ list, new intensity vector

Parameters

  • dict_fc â€“ dict of Fragility curve objects, can be generated using build_fragility_curve_database(simulationName)

  • xnew â€“ list, new intensity vector

Return fig

matplotlib.pyplot figure

Return ax

matplotlib.pyplot axis

Uses spline to interpolate the fragility curve data to a new x array. values above 1 are cliped. Plots the original data and the interpolated data for all fragility curves

Parameters

geospatial_generator(geodata1, geodata2, delta_km)ïƒ
Parameters

  • geodata1 â€“ network.Geodata, first corner of the geospactial range covered by the hazard

  • geodata2 â€“ network.Geodata, second corner of the geospactial range covered by the hazard

  • delta_km â€“ float, geospatial resolution of the intensity data in km

Return Hazard.latitudes

np.array, range of latitudes covered by the hazard

Return Hazard.longitudes

np.array, range of longitudes covered by the hazard

Calculated the geospatial ranges covered by the hazard

get_intensity(lon, lat, startTime=None, endTime=None)ïƒ
Parameters

  • lon â€“ float, in degrees

  • lat â€“ float, in degrees

  • startTime â€“ DateTime, default= start of hazard

  • endTime â€“ DateTime, default= end of hazard

Return t

list, DateTime list

Return att

list, float list of the intensity values for the given time frame

The nearest longitude at lattitude values available in the ncdf file will be returned. if the lon and lat are outside the range provided in the ncdf file a value of zero is returned.

It is possible to convert strings to the correct datetime format using pd.to_datetime()

grid_generator(max_intensity, max_radius)ïƒ
Parameters

  • max_intensity â€“ float, the rated intensity used for p.u. values in the trajectory data.

  • max_radius â€“ float, value given in km. the rated radius used for p.u. values in the trajectory data.

Return df

pandas.DataFrame, contains all the geospatial and temporal data with the intensity values.

Creates an .nc file from the pandas dataframe containing the intensity for different geospacial and temporal points. the file will be created in: file/input/project name/hazards/

hazardFromStaticInput(filename, max_intensity, max_radius, sdate, edate, geodata1, geodata2, delta_km, epicenter_lat, epicenter_lon, frequency='1H', epicenter_radius=1, epicenter_intensity=1)ïƒ
Parameters

  • filename â€“ string, filename of the csv file. Must end with .csv and must be in the directory: file/input/project name/hazards/

  • max_intensity â€“ float, the rated intensity used for p.u. values in the trajectory data.

  • max_radius â€“ float, the rated radius used for p.u. values in the trajectory data.

  • sdate â€“ datetime, start time of the hazard event, can be generated using datetime.date(year,month,day)

  • edate â€“ datetime, end time of the hazard event, can be generated using datetime.date(year,month,day)

  • geodata1 â€“ network.Geodata, first corner of the geospactial range covered by the hazard

  • geodata2 â€“ network.Geodata, second corner of the geospactial range covered by the hazard

  • delta_km â€“ float, geospatial resolution of the intensity data in km

  • epicenter_lat â€“ float, latitude of the epicenter of the hazard event

  • epicenter_lon â€“ float, longitude of the epicenter of the hazard event

  • frequency â€“ string, time intervals, default=â€™1Hâ€™

  • epicenter_radius â€“ float, radius of the hazard event from the epicenter in p.u., default = 1 p.u.

  • epicenter_intensity â€“ float, intensity of the hazard event at the epicenter in p.u., default = 1 p.u.

Initializes the Hazard object using the inputs provided.

read_nc(filename)ïƒ
Parameters

filename (string) â€“ filename of the nc file. Must end with .nc and must be in the directory: file/input/project name/hazards/

Returns

  • cols: (list)

  • Hazard.lon: (array) - list of the longitudes covered by the hazard

  • Hazard.lat: (array) - list of the latitude covered by the hazard

  • Hazard.time: (array) - list of the datetimes covered by the hazard

  • Hazard.intensity: (array) - intensity of the hazard event for each datetime, lat and lon

Return type

tuple

Reads the nc file provided in file/input/project name/hazards/ and populates the hazards attributes.

Parameters

  • intensity_unit â€“ string, the unit of the intensity used for the ncdf file, default=â€™m/sâ€™

  • intensity_name â€“ string, the attribute name of the intensity used for the ncdf file, default=â€™wind speedâ€™

  • title â€“ string, title used for the ncdf file, default=â€™Sythetic stormâ€™

Creates an .nc file from the pandas dataframe containing the intensity for different geospacial and temporal points. the file will be created in: file/input/project name/hazards/

calculate_outages_schedule(simulationTime, hazardTime)ïƒ

outagesSchedule = 1 if powerElement is available

calculate_switches_schedule(simulationTime)ïƒ

Switches will negate â€˜closed_â€™ state iif at least one of its disconnecting_element is in outagesSchedule and its value is zero. This is done by a XNOR between closed_ values and previous condition. switchesSchedule = 1 iif switch is closed OBS: If a powerElement is excluded from self.outagesSchedule (e.g. i_montecarlo = True) then it will play no role on the determination of its associated switchesâ€™ status.

propagate_schedules_to_network_elements()ïƒ

Assigns â€˜in_serviceâ€™ field based on outagesSchedule for powerElements Assigns â€˜closedâ€™ field based on switchesSchedule for switches

update_failure_probability(intensity=None, ref_return_period=None)ïƒ

This function updates the failure probability of the power elements of the network. The event object must be defined before calling this method. If this method is called the failure probabilities entered in the excel file will not be considered.

Simulationïƒ

class reXplan.simulation.Sim(simulationName)ïƒ

The Sim class contains information of the updated power grid, including the outage schedule of power elements, based on the probability of failure and hazard intensity.

initialize_model_rp(network, mc_iteration_factor, ref_return_period, cv=0.1, max_mc_iterations=10000, nStrataSamples=10000, min_intensity=None, max_intensity=None, maxStrata=10)ïƒ

The initialize_model_rp() function utilizes return periods, which needs to be defined in /file/input/project name/returnPeriods/. It uses the R module StratifiedSampling to divide the total event intensity range into strata to reduce uncertainty and computational load. A number of outage schedules is created for the Monte Carlo analysis per stratum, which are collected and stored in the outage schedule file (montecarlo_database.csv). The schedule holds the equipment status information (in-service, out-of-service, awating repair, etc.) for the simulation timeseries. The number of Monte Carlo iterations is optimized by the R module.

The file is stored at /file/output/project name/.

Parameters

  • network â€“ Class variable with network topology, elements, and their properties.

  • mc_iteration_factor â€“ Number of Monte Carlo iterations per stratum sample. Strata samples are calculated using the StratifiedSampling module of R.

  • ref_return_period â€“ Reference return period for fragility curves. Used to generate samples for the Monte Carlo simulation.

  • cv â€“ Coefficient of variation. Measure of variability of a dataset relative to its mean. Used to control the precision of the Monte Carlo simulation. A smaller value of cv will result in a more precise simulation, but will also increase computational time.

  • max_mc_iterations â€“ Limit of Monte Carlo iterations performed during the simulation.

  • nStrataSamples â€“ Number of intensity samples from return period used for the stratification.

  • min_intensity â€“ Minimum intensity of return periods

  • max_intensity â€“ Maximum intensity of return periods

  • maxStrata â€“ Maximum number of strata samples

Network type

reXplan.network.Network

Mc_iteration_factor type

int

Ref_return_period type

str

Cv type

float

Max_mc_iterations type

int

NStrataSamples type

int

Min_intensity type

float

Max_intensity type

float

initialize_model_sh(network, mc_iterations)ïƒ

The initialize_model_sh() function calculates the probability of failure for the electrical components in the network and applies the Monte Carlo Method to create/update the outage schedule for the Montecarlo Analysis (montecarlo_database.csv). This schedule holds the equipment status information (in-service, out-of-service, awating repair, etc.) for the simulation timeseries. Increasing the number of Monte Carlo iterations reduces uncertainty, but increases computational load.

The file is stored at /file/output/project name/.

Parameters

  • network â€“ Class variable with network topology, elements, and their properties.

  • mc_iterations â€“ Number of Monte Carlo iterations.

Network type

reXplan.network.Network

Mc_iterations type

int

Returns

outages schedule of the network

Return type

pandas.core.frame.DataFrame

run(network, iterationSet=None, saveOutput=True, time=None, debug=None, **kwargs)ïƒ

The run() function uses the outage schedule (montecarlo_database.csv), generated using one of the initialize functions. A timeseries OPF is executed for the provided network object and updates engine_database.csv with the OPF results.

The file is stored file/output/project name/, if saveOutput = True.

Parameters

  • network â€“ Contains information about the network topology, elements, and their properties. See Network class.

  • iterationSet â€“ If provided, selected Monte Carlo iterations will be selected. If not provided, all iterations will be executed.

  • saveOutput â€“ Determines whether the output database should be saved to a file (engine_database.csv) or not.

  • time â€“ Specifies the duration of the simulation. If provided, it will override the default simulation time set in the self.time variable. See Time class.

  • run_type â€“

    (of **kwargs) can utilize different OPF approaches:

    -> dc_opf - pypower (Python)

    -> ac_opf - pypower (Python)

    -> pm_dc_opf - PandaModels (Julia)

    -> pm_ac_opf - PandaModels (Julia)

    PandaModels is recommended, as PandaModels has better convergence properties.

Network type

reXplan.network.Network object

IterationSet type

list

SaveOutput type

bool

Time type

class

Run_type type

string

class reXplan.simulation.Time(start, duration)ïƒ

Contains information about the simulation time. :param start: Starting point of the simulation interval. It is an integer value that indicates the first value in the interval :param duration: Represents the length of the interval in units of time :start type: int :duration type: int
